issue.title: create deb package and retain as artifact
issue.body:
In pursuit of https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues/94 this PR prepares (for) binary releases (to be added to release packages, for example).

The binary is intentionally created to
- only contain the standardized algorithms ("STD")
- only use OpenSSL3 APIs (so it can seamlessly be integrated to Â´oqsproviderÂ´)
- be built shared (such as to permit independent `dpkg -i`(installs))

Suggestions for other setups welcome. Suggestions where (else) to store the artifact also welcome (www.openquantumsafe.org?)

* [no] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [no] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: I'm not familiar with this feature of Github. What does it mean to preserve it as an artifact?  Is it turned into a release?  Or is there some other place it's available?

> @dstebila When this merges, please also feel free to turn off the Windows VM you kindly made available for helping me test this platform.

I only read the last clause of that sentence, so I already turned it off. ðŸ˜ Let me know if you need it back on.

issue.title: document specs [skip ci]
issue.body:
Fixes #189.

@dstebila I'd be glad if you could check/improve this, possibly amending the references and/or the background from https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/wiki/Integrating-PQC-into-TLS-1.3 -- best without reference to a Wiki: It'd be nice if all standards could be incorporated in github (and thus, future releases). Hence just a draft PR for now.

comment.body:
> @dstebila I'd be glad if you could check/improve this, possibly amending the references and/or the background from https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/wiki/Integrating-PQC-into-TLS-1.3 -- best without reference to a Wiki: It'd be nice if all standards could be incorporated in github (and thus, future releases). Hence just a draft PR for now.

I gave an attempt at doing so; please proof read and edit. Main idea was to give it more structure. Not sure if that's what you're looking for.

issue.body:
In pursuit of https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues/94 this PR prepares (for) binary releases (to be added to release packages, for example).

The binary is intentionally created to
- only contain the standardized algorithms ("STD")
- only use OpenSSL3 APIs (so it can seamlessly be integrated to Â´oqsproviderÂ´)
- be built shared (such as to permit independent `dpkg -i`(installs))

Suggestions for other setups welcome. Suggestions where (else) to store the artifact also welcome (www.openquantumsafe.org?)

* [no] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [no] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> I'm not familiar with this feature of Github. What does it mean to preserve it as an artifact? Is it turned into a release? Or is there some other place it's available?

Github artifacts are documented [here](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/storing-workflow-data-as-artifacts). They are retained ([and can be downloaded](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/downloading-workflow-artifacts?tool=webui)) for some time after the build, e.g., if they "stood the test of time" to then be made (either manually or via specific code: download & store to some place) available wherever one sees fit (e.g., in binaries linked to releases). This PR does not contain such "automated deploy code": We'd first need to decide where to send it to -- and under which conditions.

issue.title: create deb package and retain as artifact
issue.body:
In pursuit of https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues/94 this PR prepares (for) binary releases (to be added to release packages, for example).

The binary is intentionally created to
- only contain the standardized algorithms ("STD")
- only use OpenSSL3 APIs (so it can seamlessly be integrated to Â´oqsproviderÂ´)
- be built shared (such as to permit independent `dpkg -i`(installs))

Suggestions for other setups welcome. Suggestions where (else) to store the artifact also welcome (www.openquantumsafe.org?)

* [no] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [no] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
For further clarification: With https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/196 and this PR landing, deployment of `liboqs` on an x64 Linux with OpenSSL3 present then simply consists of running ` dpkg -i liboqs-0.8.1-dev-Linux.deb`. This step of course is not necessary if `liboqs` has already been integrated to & installed via the package management system of the distribution used.

Subsequent installation of `oqsprovider` then is simply `dpkg -i oqs-provider-0.5.1-dev-Linux.deb`. After this, one can operate `openssl` with all OQS alg combinations (again, assuming they have `openssl` >= 3.0 installed and activated `oqsprovider`). Again, `dpkg -i` would not be necessary any more if/when `oqsprovider` is integrated to the distribution's package management system.

issue.title: Question: How do I verify that a connection uses a quantum kem in OQS-OpenSSL_1_0_2-stable
issue.body:
Hi,

I know the branch is deprecated, but I am studying the implementation to understand what is required to support quantum kems in TLS1.2/DTLS1.2.

So I've built the OQS-OpenSSL_1_0_2-stable version and now I want to verify that a quantum kem is used by the tls key exchange.

Should I just look at the s_client output
```
SSL-Session:
    Protocol  : TLSv1.2
    Cipher    : OQSKEM-DEFAULT-ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
```
In order to verify that a quantum kem was used?
And is there a way to change the quantum kem? From the source code it looks like the default kem maps to a SIKE variant, and I'd like to test with Kyber. My assumption is I just change the definition OQS_KEM_DEFAULT in liboqs?

Here are the commands I used:
```
./apps/openssl s_server -cert rsa_srv.crt -key rsa_srv.key -tls1_2
./apps/openssl s_client -tls1_2 -cipher OQSKEM-DEFAULT-ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
```

comment.body:
> My assumption is I just change the definition OQS_KEM_DEFAULT in liboqs?

Probably right. But we removed the concept of default algs quite some time ago from `liboqs`, so you'd (also) only be able to use pretty dated versions of `liboqs`.

May I ask what is your rationale to dive into such old versions of the code (and TLS)?

issue.title: Question: How do I verify that a connection uses a quantum kem in OQS-OpenSSL_1_0_2-stable
issue.body:
Hi,

I know the branch is deprecated, but I am studying the implementation to understand what is required to support quantum kems in TLS1.2/DTLS1.2.

So I've built the OQS-OpenSSL_1_0_2-stable version and now I want to verify that a quantum kem is used by the tls key exchange.

Should I just look at the s_client output
```
SSL-Session:
    Protocol  : TLSv1.2
    Cipher    : OQSKEM-DEFAULT-ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
```
In order to verify that a quantum kem was used?
And is there a way to change the quantum kem? From the source code it looks like the default kem maps to a SIKE variant, and I'd like to test with Kyber. My assumption is I just change the definition OQS_KEM_DEFAULT in liboqs?

Here are the commands I used:
```
./apps/openssl s_server -cert rsa_srv.crt -key rsa_srv.key -tls1_2
./apps/openssl s_client -tls1_2 -cipher OQSKEM-DEFAULT-ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
```

comment.body:
As I previously stated in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/issues/454 I am interested in the support of quantum key exchanges in DTLS. 

As a first step: I wanted to check if quantum key exchanges is supported in DTLS1.2 with the implementation in OQS-OpenSSL_1_0_2-stable. And it looks like DTLS is supported in this old revision if what I posted is the correct way to verify that a connection was established with a quantum kem.

Now I'd like to understand the best way to achieve the overall goal of DTLS support. I'd like to hear from you if you think there's something I need to know? Otherwise I will continue studying past and present implementations to get up to speed on the OpenSSL implementation.

issue.title: Question: How do I verify that a connection uses a quantum kem in OQS-OpenSSL_1_0_2-stable
issue.body:
Hi,

I know the branch is deprecated, but I am studying the implementation to understand what is required to support quantum kems in TLS1.2/DTLS1.2.

So I've built the OQS-OpenSSL_1_0_2-stable version and now I want to verify that a quantum kem is used by the tls key exchange.

Should I just look at the s_client output
```
SSL-Session:
    Protocol  : TLSv1.2
    Cipher    : OQSKEM-DEFAULT-ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
```
In order to verify that a quantum kem was used?
And is there a way to change the quantum kem? From the source code it looks like the default kem maps to a SIKE variant, and I'd like to test with Kyber. My assumption is I just change the definition OQS_KEM_DEFAULT in liboqs?

Here are the commands I used:
```
./apps/openssl s_server -cert rsa_srv.crt -key rsa_srv.key -tls1_2
./apps/openssl s_client -tls1_2 -cipher OQSKEM-DEFAULT-ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
```

comment.body:
If memory serves, we never worked on or tested DTLS, even in this old branch. Maybe it works, maybe it doesn't. 

As for seeing if a post-quantum key exchange is being used, you can use use some of the s_client and s_server command line options to print out what algorithms end up being used, and you can also inspect the connection in Wireshark; though an unmodified Wireshark will not recognize the algorithm identifiers used, it should still at least say something like "unknown algorithm" which would be an indication that post-quantum was being used.
